tossups.question: At the end of this book, its author describes its purpose as an "extended apology for my success". This book describes the owner of a horse farm in Missouri who lost a scholarship to Reed College because his mother forgot to fill out a renewal form. This book, which derives a conclusion about math tests from the differences in work required for rice and wheat harvests, opens with a discussion of the Matthew Effect to explain why early (*) months of the year are more likely to contain the birthdays of elite hockey players. This book, which cites access to IBM's board of directors and a computer center as reasons for the success of Bill Gates, puts forth its author's "10,000-Hour Rule" for mastery in a field. For 10 points, name this Malcolm Gladwell book about anomalous individuals.
tossups.answer: Outliers
tossups.answer_formatted: Outliers

tossups.question: The royal prerogative to income from this good was asserted in the Great Law Code of 1649, which outlawed private korchmy. Penalties of amounts of this good were used by Peter the Great to prevent government employees from being late to work. The Tatar system of supplying kabaks inspired the state monopoly on this good created by Ivan the Terrible, which provided about a third of later tsars' revenue. In a widely-reproduced Soviet poster, a man in a (*) blue suit extends his palm to reject this good, saying "Nyet!" An increase in male life expectancy by three years resulted from Mikhail Gorbachev's order that state companies, such as Stoli, produce fruit juice instead of this good. A name meaning "little water" is given to a variety of, for 10 points, what good whose brands include Smirnoff?
tossups.answer: alcohol [accept vodka or hard alcohol or spirits or liquor or booze or distilled grain; prompt on wine or beer by saying "we want a more general answer"]
tossups.answer_formatted: alcohol [accept vodka or hard alcohol or spirits or liquor or booze or distilled grain; prompt on wine or beer by saying "we want a more general answer]
promptable: beer by saying "we want a more general answer

tossups.question: This author included a poem about a treasurer who receives a bride from the Caliph, titled "The Gift of Harun al-Raschid," in a book featuring the spirit of Leo Africanus. This Theosophist made automatic writing with his wife Georgie. This poet's collection A Wind Among the Reeds features his recurring character Aedh wishing for "cloths of heaven". This poet wrote that "peace comes dropping slow / dropping from the veils of the morning" in a place where noon has a (*) "purple glow" in a poem which refers to Tarot numerology with its line about planting "nine-bean rows" near a "small cabin". His world-view centered on the "gyres" in which the world is "turning and turning" in his best-known poem. The line "I will arise and go now" begins the poem "The Lake Isle of Innisfree" by, for 10 points, what poet of "The Second Coming"?
tossups.answer: William Butler Yeats ("yates") [or W. B. Yeats]
tossups.answer_formatted: William Butler Yeats

tossups.question: STRAD-alpha and the Tribbles family are examples of the catalytically inactive "pseudo" form of these enzymes, which comprise about 10% of these enzymes in the human genome. Some inhibitors of these enzymes may gain access to a hydrophobic binding pocket by interacting with a so-called "gatekeeper residue". One of these enzymes activates the ULK1 and VPS34 complexes to initiate autophagy; that enzyme, called mammalian target-of-rapamycin, also activates insulin receptors. Many (*) signal transduction pathways, such as one triggered by MAP, use a cascade of these enzymes to alter internal cellular activity. The classification of these enzymes depends on whether they act on tyrosine, or on serine and threonine. For 10 points, what enzymes add phosphate groups to their substrates?
tossups.answer: kinases
tossups.answer_formatted: kinases

tossups.question: In a 1972 Playboy interview, this architect used the metaphor of a "trim tab [building] a low pressure" to explain how people can empower themselves. The "Barwise" and "Danbury" were two prototypes of a house designed by this architect that contained "O-volving" shelves and were made entirely of aluminum. This architect proposed creating floating spherical habitats known as "Cloud Nine," which would be held together using (*) "tensegrity". This architect described his ethos as "doing more with less," exemplified by a term he coined, "dymaxion". For Expo 67, this architect created a biosphere that distributes stress over polyhedra consisting of solely triangular faces. For 10 points, name this architect famous for geodesic domes, who lends his name to a molecule consisting of 60 carbon atoms.
tossups.answer: (Richard) Buckminster Fuller

tossups.question: Curves corresponding to this type of process on a log-log plot of shear modulus vs time are constructed in a "superposition" method used to study the rheology of polymers. In another context, curves corresponding to this type of process are modeled empirically by equating a mass ratio to a constant, K, times pressure raised to the "one over n" power. The work done by this type of process acting on an (*) ideal gas is proportional to the logarithm of the ratio of final to initial volume. A polytropic index of one indicates this type of process. First-order phase transitions are this type of process, which corresponds to a horizontal line on a T-S diagram. A Carnot cycle contains two adiabatic steps and two steps with, for 10 points, what property, meaning temperature remains constant?
tossups.answer: isothermal process [accept isotherms; prompt on adsorption by asking "what property does that adsorption curve have?" prompt on compression or expansion]
tossups.answer_formatted: isothermal process [accept isotherms; prompt on adsorption by asking "what property does that adsorption curve have? or compression or expansion]
promptable: adsorption by asking "what property does that adsorption curve have?

tossups.question: When the Kabul Museum displayed what it claimed was an object used for this task, it caused an international incident with India, as that object was reportedly left to the people of Vaishali ("vie-SHAH-lee"). A type of staff with metal rings on top was meant both to ward off animals and to aid in this task. The term bhikkhu literally refers to doing this task; Buddhist monks were originally only allowed to own three robes and an item used for this task. Theravada ("tair-uh-VAH-duh") monks make daily (*) processions for this task. The Theravada ban on monastic vegetarianism is due to the strictness of their requirement of this practice; in Theravada tradition, the Buddha died from eating spoiled pork as a result of doing this practice. For 10 points, Buddhist monks are supposed to survive by what practice of asking for food?
tossups.answer: begging for alms [or receiving/taking/etc. alms; or alms rounds; or mendicancy or being a mendicant; accept clear equivalents of any of the preceding answers; before "bhikkhu", accept bhikkha or bhiksha; prompt on just alms; do not accept or prompt on "dana" or on things like "giving alms"; prompt on asceticism or similar general answers; before mentioned, prompt on answers that just mention things like eating or food]
tossups.answer_formatted: begging for alms [or receiving/taking/etc. alms; or alms rounds; or mendicancy or being a mendicant; accept clear equivalents of any of the preceding answers; before "bhikkhu", accept bhikkha or bhiksha; prompt on just alms; do not accept or prompt on "dana" or "on things like "giving alms"; prompt on asceticism or similar general answers; before mentioned, prompt on answers that just mention things like eating or food]
acceptable: clear equivalents of any of the preceding answers

tossups.question: In one story, one of these figures says "Vous serez ma proie" ("voo seh-RAY mah pwah") to a soldier found cycling through the countryside who enters the title "House of Love". Two of these figures who live in Sorrento frequent a lemonade stand in the title story of a collection by Karen Russell. In another story, one of these figures kills the woman Ianthe ("eye-ON-thee"), unbeknownst to his travelling companion John Aubrey. In a novel, one of these figures brings 50 boxes of (*) soil aboard the Russian ship Demeter. The misleading attribution "A Tale by Lord Byron" was given to a story featuring one of these figures named Lord Ruthven by John Polidori. Another of these figures pursues Lucy Westenra and is defeated by Abraham van Helsing. For 10 points, name these title creatures of Bram Stoker's Dracula.
tossups.answer: vampires [accept Vampires in the Lemon Grove or "The Vampyre"; prompt on countesses or counts or lords or ladies or nobles] (The story "The Lady of the House of Love" is by Angela Carter.)
tossups.answer_formatted: vampires [accept Vampires in the Lemon Grove or The Vampyre; prompt on countesses or counts or lords or ladies or nobles]
tossups.metadata: The story "The Lady of the House of Love" is by Angela Carter.

tossups.question: In 1910, British archaeologists discovered a sculpted head of this ruler lying underneath a temple in Meroë. A temple to Diana stood next to one named after this ruler in the Croatian city of Pula. A temple dedicated to this ruler known as the Monumentum Ancyranum contains a copy of his funerary inscription, whose name translates roughly as "things done". This ruler ordered the construction of the Temple of (*) Mars Ultor after he retrieved the battle standards lost at the Battle of Carrhae. This ruler, whose deeds are listed in the Res Gestae, points outwards on a statue named for the villa of his third wife, Livia Drusilla. Coins issued by him often bore the inscription "divi filius," referring to the "divine" status of his adoptive father. For 10 points, what ruler took the title princeps after founding the Roman Empire?
tossups.answer: Augustus [accept Gaius Octavius; accept Octavian]
tossups.answer_formatted: Augustus [accept Gaius Octavius; accept Octavian]

tossups.question: Art historian Tarnya Cooper curated an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery titled "Searching for" this person. X-ray analysis revealed that a portrait of this person dated to the 1800s was painted over a 1609 depiction of the Madonna and Child. The phrase "Principum amicitas!" appears above this person in a painting owned by the Cobbe family. This person is depicted in both the fake "Flower Portrait" and in an engraving by (*) Martin Droeshout; the latter may be modeled on John Taylor's portrait of this person, which was owned by the Duke of Chandos. Elizabeth Siddal posed in a bathtub for a painting inspired by this author's work that depicts a woman floating in a brook, by John Everett Millais. For 10 points, an engraving of what author appears on the cover of his First Folio?
tossups.answer: William Shakespeare
tossups.answer_formatted: William Shakespeare

tossups.question: This organization's textbook Preachers, Not Judges was written by its second "supreme guide". Throughout the 1950s, the CIA funded a leader of this group, Said Ramadan, to promote anti-communism. The protest movement Tamarod collected millions of signatures opposing this group's main political vehicle, the Freedom and Justice Party. Its first meeting place was created in Ismailia by its founder (*) Hassan al-Bannah ("HAH-sen al-buh-NAH"). Many of this group's members were arrested in 1954 over an alleged attempt to kill the leader of the Free Officers Movement. This group gained political power in the aftermath of the 2011 Tahrir Square protests, but was overthrown in 2013 by the army under Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. Egyptian president Mohammed Morsi was part of, for 10 points, what pan-Islamic organization?
tossups.answer: Muslim Brotherhood [or Society of the Muslim Brothers; or Jamāʿat al-Ikhwān al-Muslimīn; accept Freedom and Justice Party or Ḥizb al-Ḥurriyyah wa-l-ʿAdālah before mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: Muslim Brotherhood [or Society of the Muslim Brothers; or Jamāʿat al-Ikhwān al-Muslimīn; accept Freedom and Justice Partyaccept Ḥizb al-Ḥurriyyah wa-l-ʿAdālah before mentioned]

tossups.question: A woman in this novel points out of a window to a maple tree which the protagonist urinated on many years ago. Another woman in this novel spends 20 years collecting rocks and hangs a bag from her ceiling containing human bones. After meeting with Reverend Cooper, its protagonist learns his grandfather's body washed up from the grave. The phrase "your day has come" is whispered to victims by this novel's characters Empire State and Hospital Tommy, who are part of a (*) revenge killing society called Seven Days. Reba's daughter Hagar tries to kill this novel's protagonist, who learns to "fly" after Pilate is killed. While searching for a bag of gold, this novel's protagonist is almost killed by Guitar. Milkman Dead features in, for 10 points, what Toni Morrison novel with a biblical title?
tossups.answer: Song of Solomon
tossups.answer_formatted: Song of Solomon

tossups.question: One of these instruments called a doira is commonly found in shashmaqam ensembles. A technique for playing these instruments called "tek" is used for playing Beledi and Maqsoum music in Egypt. Syahi paste is applied to tune one of these instruments from the Indian subcontinent which produces syllables known as bols, and which consists of a dayan and bayan. One of these instruments which is commonly called a (*) doumbek or darbouka commonly provides accompaniment to belly dance music. These instruments are often hourglass-shaped in North and West Africa, including a skin-covered "goblet" variant called the djembe, which skilled performers are said to make "talk". The tabla is an example of, for 10 points, what percussion instruments that include a "snare" variety?
tossups.answer: drums [accept goblet drums; accept djembe or tabla before either is read; prompt on percussion]
tossups.answer_formatted: drums [accept goblet drums; accept djembeaccept tabla before either is read; prompt on percussion]

tossups.question: In this technique, the signal is proportional to a parameter denoted Z and calculated by a sum over all particles of the sixth power of diameter. In this technique, increasing the PRF increases the unambiguous velocity, but decreases the unambiguous range, a trade-off called this technique's namesake "dilemma". It's not interferometry, but the "dual polarization" form of this technique measures data on the size and shape of particles. A signature called a (*) "hook echo" in this technique indicates the presence of a mesocyclone. This technique measures the phase shift between successive pulses, which is non-zero because the motion of hydrometeor droplets triggers the Doppler effect. For 10 points, name this technique in which reflected radio and microwaves allow for mapping of precipitation.
tossups.answer: Doppler radar [or weather radar; prompt on Doppler dilemma] (The first sentence refers to the reflectivity factor.)
tossups.answer_formatted: Doppler radar [or weather radar; prompt on Doppler dilemma]
tossups.metadata: The first sentence refers to the reflectivity factor.

tossups.question: Medieval Christians identified a form of this pagan deity with the Virgin Mary. Like Agdistis, Cybele, and Elagabalus, this Classical deity was originally enshrined as an aniconic black stone. In Sparta and on a nearby island, this deity was oddly worshiped as a war deity with the epithet Areia. A Homeric hymn numbers Artemis among the three phrenes, or minds, that this "smile-loving" deity cannot overcome. This deity had (*) "popular" and "heavenly" forms named Pandemos and Ourania. Greek worship of this goddess likely began when Phoenician traders on Cyprus and Cythera introduced the cult of Astarte. This goddess was said to be born from sea foam produced by Uranus's severed genitals. The Judgment of Paris was won by, for 10 points, what goddess of love?
tossups.answer: Aphrodite [or Venus; accept Venus Urania, Aphrodite Areia, Aphrodite Pandemos, or Aphrodite Ourania; do not accept or prompt on just "Urania"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Aphrodite [or Venus; accept Venus Urania, Aphrodite Areia, Aphrodite Pandemos, or Aphrodite Ourania; do not accept or prompt on "just "Urania"]
acceptable: Venus Urania, Aphrodite Areia, Aphrodite Pandemos,

tossups.question: The protagonist of one novel drinks whisky while chatting about the greatness of this person with Itoh before calling Midori ("mee-doh-ree"). In a 2017 novel titled in reference to a work by this person, Long Face opens the door to an underworld full of double metaphors after the protagonist uses a fishing knife to re-enact a murder scene with Tomohiko Okada. A character created by this non-Japanese person is the "bird-catcher man" referred to in The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle. In a play later adapted into a (*) film, an asylum inmate confesses to trying to poison this man at the court of Joseph II. A character from one of this man's operas comes to life in Haruki Murakami's novel Killing Commendatore ("kuh-MEN-duh-TORE-ay"). For 10 points, name this composer whose rivalry with Salieri is depicted in Peter Shaffer's play Amadeus.
tossups.answer: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (The "bird-catcher man" is Papageno from The Magic Flute)
tossups.answer_formatted: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
tossups.metadata: The "bird-catcher man" is Papageno from The Magic Flute

tossups.question: Reversals of feeding and bleeding orders can result in this subfield's namesake type of "opacity". A non-linear formalism in this subfield put forth by John Goldsmith uses an "association convention" to define how units are organized based on autosegmental rules. Bruce Hayes, the author of a textbook on this subfield, proposed an algorithm to derive constraints for it from optimality theory. In a book often called "SPE" which extends their work on (*) grammar, Chomsky and Halle developed a "generative" approach to this subfield to study processes that affect distinctive features, such as velar softening in English. Like historical linguistics, it examines the effects of such changes as de-aspiration, chain shifts, and stressing of syllables. For 10 points, name this subfield of linguistics which studies how languages organize sound.
tossups.answer: phonology [accept phonological opacity or autosegmental phonology or phonological analysis; prompt on linguistics before "linguistics"; do not accept or prompt on "phonetics"]
tossups.answer_formatted: phonology [accept phonological opacity or autosegmental phonology or phonological analysis; prompt on linguistics before "linguistics; do not accept or prompt on "phonetics"]

tossups.question: An analysis of the "place of the furies" concludes a "study" of this philosophical movement by William Barrett. An essay on this movement contrasts a central thesis with the example of a paper-knife, for which a sum of "formulae and qualities" makes "definition possible". A history of it by Walter Kaufmann ("VAL-tur COWF-mahn") examines its core question of "What is Transcendence?" The Communist reproach that this movement is an "an invitation to...dwell in (*) quietism" is addressed in a lecture that names its major Christian proponents as Karl Jaspers ("YAHS-spurs") and Gabriel Marcel. That lecture defends this movement's emphasis on "pure subjectivity," declares it to be "a Humanism," and claims its central subject "precedes essence". The book Being and Nothingness advances, for 10 points, what philosophy of Jean-Paul Sartre ("SAR-truh")?
tossups.answer: existentialism [or existential philosophy; accept Existentialism from Dostoevsky to Sartre or "Existentialism is a Humanism"] (Barrett's book is Irrational Man.)
tossups.answer_formatted: existentialism [or existential philosophy; accept Existentialism from Dostoevsky to Sartre or Existentialism is a Humanism]

tossups.question: In a 2015 majority opinion, Sonia Sotomayor argued that a municipal law requiring these institutions to keep records violated the 4th Amendment in Los Angeles v. Patel. Archibald Cox used the example of a hypothetical road trip between Washington D.C. and Miami to argue against another one of these institutions. Charles Evans Hughes determined that some of these places in Washington state were subject to a (*) minimum wage law in a 1937 case whose plaintiff was Elsie Parrish, and which ended the "Lochner Era". In a 1964 case, Moreton Rolleston argued that his institution of this kind maintained the right to discriminate against patrons on the basis of the Commerce Clause. The Civil Rights Act was upheld in a Supreme Court case regarding, for 10 points, what sort of institution named "Heart of Atlanta"?
tossups.answer: hotels [or motels]
tossups.answer_formatted: hotels [or motels]

tossups.question: The processing of this material may involve a step abbreviated OZEPY, an example of a sequence that is "totally chlorine free" due to environmental concerns. Residual impurity content in this material is quantified by the kappa number. The "virgin" form of this material generally has higher mechanical strength than the alternative. The synthesis of this material involves digestion with a mixture of sodium hydroxide and sodium sulfide called "white liquor"; that chemical treatment is the first step of the (*) kraft process. In a common commercial application, lignin and hemicellulose fibers are removed from this material, which is then bleached, dried, and pulled into flat sheets. For 10 points, name this wood-derived material used to make paper.
tossups.answer: wood pulp [prompt on paper by asking "what is the precursor to that?"; prompt on wood or cellulose or lignin or hemicellulose]
tossups.answer_formatted: wood pulp [prompt on paper by asking "what is the precursor to that?; prompt on wood or cellulose or lignin or hemicellulose]
promptable: paper by asking "what is the precursor to that?

bonuses.leadin: This author played the role of Mrs. Hale in the first performance of her play Trifles, based on a murder she reported on in Des Moines. For 10 points each:
answers: Alison Stanhope [accept either underlined portion; accept Alison's House]
parts: Name this American playwright who, with her husband George Cook, founded the Provincetown Players, the first modern theater company in the U.S.
Glaspell is credited with discovering this playwright and launched his career in 1916 by having the Provincetown Players put on his play Anna Christie. This man also wrote The Iceman Cometh.
Glaspell fictionalized Emily Dickinson as this deceased poet, whose residence is sold 18 years after her death, in a play that won Glaspell a Pulitzer for Drama.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about digital tools and techniques used by music producers:
answers: Musical Instrument Digital Interface or MIDI [accept Black MIDI]
parts: This three-word name denotes digital applications used by producers to create music, such as FL Studio, Ableton Live, and Cubase.

Producers add instruments to their tracks by drawing notes in a file encoded in this standard or by plugging in a controller and playing notes. A so-called "black" genre of music named for this file standard often has millions of notes in its remixes.
To make melodies less loud, producers use this technique which reduces the dynamic range of an audio signal. As in computing, this technique may be "lossy" or "lossless".
answers_formatted: Musical Instrument Digital Interface or MIDI [accept Black MIDI]
acceptable: Musical Instrument Digital Interface or MIDI

bonuses.leadin: The speed of this phenomenon can be determined from Laszlo Tisza's "two-fluid" model by linearizing the equations of motion and rearrranging to produce a pair of wave equations. For 10 points each:
answers: second sound [do not accept or prompt on just "sound" or equivalents]
thermal conductivity [prompt on heat conductivity; do not accept or prompt on "conductivity"]
parts: Name these undamped longitudinal temperature waves that allow for efficient heat transfer.
Second sound is a phenomenon seen in these substances, which have unusual flow properties due to their zero viscosity.

Second sound causes superfluid helium to have a very high value of this quantity. Symbolized k, it is the proportionality constant between the heat flux and the temperature gradient in the heat equation.
answers_formatted: second sound [do not accept or prompt on "just "sound" do not accept or prompt on equivalents]
thermal conductivity [prompt on heat conductivity; do not accept or prompt on "conductivity"]

bonuses.leadin: Helen Frankenthaler often mixed her oil paints with turpentine to create the appearance of watercolor through this technique. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this technique, used in works like Mountains and Sea, in which Frankenthaler poured diluted paint onto a large unprimed canvas.
In contrast to Frankenthaler's stains, this other color-field artist used large stripes he called "zips" in his paintings. His Vir Heroicus Sublimus is in the MoMA.

Frankenthaler displayed her work at an exhibition titled for the "post-painterly" type of this word. Another form of this word was applied to American art in 1946 to describe a type of "expressionism."

bonuses.leadin: With his fellow general Jebe, this man coordinated maneuvers across thousands of miles during his "Great Raid" through the lands of the Cumans and Rus'. For 10 points each:
answers: Subutai [or Subotai, or Subotei; prompt on Baatur]
Genghis Khan [or Chinggis Khan; accept Temujin]
deep battle [or deep operations, or glubokaya operatsiya; prompt on deep]
parts: Name this Mongol general and tactical genius known as the "Valiant Dog of War". He later captured Kaifeng ("kye-fung"), the capital of Jin.
Subutai was one of this Mongol ruler's "Four Dogs of War" and helped him conquer the Jurchens in the early 13th century.

Subutai's divide-and-conquer tactics were a major inspiration of this Soviet military theory used in World War II, which emphasized exploiting tactical success to win strategic goals and destroy the enemy's logistics.
answers_formatted: deep battle [or deep operations, or glubokaya operatsiya; prompt on deep]

bonuses.leadin: Since her father Daksha doesn't approve of her marrying an ascetic, Sati and this groom of hers aren't invited to their own wedding. For 10 points each:
parts: Name Sati's groom, the third part of the Trimurti. Known as Nataraja ("nuh-tuh-RAH-juh") or Lord of Dance, his Tandava ("TAHN-duh-vuh") dance causes destruction.
Upset by Daksha's actions, Sati self-immolates and is reborn as this goddess, also known as Uma or Gauri.

When Parvati's parents question Shiva's lineage, this sage twangs an ektara to signify that Shiva was born from reverberation. This sage inspired Valmiki, and his Purana has summaries of all eighteen major Puranas.

bonuses.leadin: Attempting to prove the "anticipatory" form of this offense is difficult, as it requires a "positive and unequivocal" expression of intent. For 10 points each:
answers: breach of contract [prompt on just breach; prompt on repudiation of contract; do not accept or prompt on "crime" or "criminal offense"]
material [accept material breach of contract, or material witness]
parts: Name this offense whose "efficient" form, as articulated by Richard Posner, may be done for economic gain. Parties sued for it typically offer affirmative defenses, such as attempting to demonstrate duress.
Breach of contract is this type of offense, which is contrasted with a criminal offense against the state.
This term denotes a breach of contract which renders it irreparably broken, thus prompting tougher legal measures. This term also denotes important witnesses in criminal trials.
answers_formatted: breach of contract [prompt on just breach; prompt on repudiation of contract; do not accept or prompt on "crime" or "criminal offense"]

bonuses.leadin: In the tenth and last of these poems, a personified Lament leads a young man through the "landscape of Lamentation" before leaving him to climb the "mountains of primeval pain". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this cycle of poems written in a namesake castle by the Adriatic. The first of them declares "Beauty is nothing but the beginning of terror".
The Duino Elegies are by this Austrian-born poet of "Archaic Torso of Apollo".

Rilke's poem "To" this author says that, to him, "a compelling image...was a life, entire". This poet's elegies, such as "The Archipelago," are laden with Greek mythological references and heavily inspired those of Rilke.

bonuses.leadin: At 75, this man won a Senate election against incumbent James L. Pugh. For 10 points each:
answers: Bloody Sunday [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this Civil War general and grand dragon of the Ku Klux Klan. Following Rep. John Lewis's death, a change.org ("change-dot-org") petition was created to rename a Selma landmark named after him.
John Lewis was one of the many who marched from this city to Selma in 1965 across the Pettus Bridge. Earlier, Martin Luther King Jr. staged a boycott of this city's busing system.
The first day of the Selma-Montgomery march became known by this name, in part due to a photo of Amelia Boynton after she was beaten unconscious on the Pettus Bridge.
answers_formatted: Bloody Sunday [do not accept or prompt on "partial answers"]

bonuses.leadin: These structures do not have the internal cavity possessed by liposomes. For 10 points each:
answers: packing parameter [accept answers that use the word "micellar," "molecular," or "surfactant" before packing parameter]
parts: Name these spherical aggregates that form above a critical concentration of phospholipids in aqueous solution.
The inner core of a micelle consists of phospholipid tails, which have this property, meaning they repel water.

Whether a given surfactant tends to form bilayers, micelles, or other structures can be predicted by this quantity, which equals the tail volume divided by the product of the tail length and the equilibrium area at the aggregate surface.
answers_formatted: packing parameter [accept answers that use the word "micellar," "molecular,accept surfactant" before packing parameter]

bonuses.leadin: Refugees have tried entering the European Union by crossing this river that demarcates the Turkey-Greece border. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Balkan river. It rises in the Rila Mountains and flows through the cities of Edirne and Plovdiv.

The Maritsa River is the primary waterway in this historical region that encompasses southern Bulgaria, western Turkey, and northeastern Greece. The Odrysians lived in a Roman province with this name.
The Maritsa's Latin name, the Evros, shares the same root with the Ebro River, which flows through this peninsula. The Tagus River is the longest on this peninsula.

bonuses.leadin: Neil Gaiman has twice won the adult fantasy fiction prize awarded by the society named for this term. For 10 points each:
answers: mythopoeia [accept Mythopoeic Prize or Mythopoeic Society; do not accept or prompt on "mythopoetic" or "mythopoeisis"]
C. S. Lewis [or Clive Staples Lewis]
Merlin [or Myrddin, or Marzhin, or Merzhin]
parts: Give this term coined by J.R.R. Tolkien for literature which creates and integrates fantasy and legend. Its name derives from the Greek for "making stories".
The Mythopoeic Society grew out of the Inklings, a group of fantasy enthusiasts including this novelist of the Chronicles of Narnia, whom Tolkien criticized in the poem "Mythopoeia".
The first Mythopoeic Prize went to Mary Stewart's novel The Crystal Cave, whose protagonist is this character from Arthurian myth. In other stories, this character teaches Morgan le Faye.
answers_formatted: mythopoeia [accept Mythopoeic Prize or Mythopoeic Society; do not accept or prompt on "mythopoetic" or "mythopoeisis"]

bonuses.leadin: The use of this concept in programming frees the programmer from specifying what objects to deallocate and return to the memory system. For 10 points each:
answers: garbage collection [accept GC, accept word forms like garbage collecting]
parts: Name this form of automatic memory management that reclaims memory occupied by objects that are no longer in use by the program.
Garbage collection reduces dangling examples of these objects, which occur when a piece of memory is freed while this object still exists. In general, these objects store memory addresses.
This compile-time technique converts heap allocations to stack allocations, reducing the garbage collection to be done. This technique determines the dynamic scope of pointers.
answers_formatted: garbage collection [accept GC, or word forms like garbage collecting]

bonuses.leadin: Within a week of capturing this country with only three losses, Napoleon abolished its Inquisition, declared religious freedom, and replaced its law code with a modern secular one. For 10 points each:

Prior to its takeover by Napoleon, Malta was run by this organization of knights, which originated during the Crusades as a group providing medical aid to pilgrims.

Britain was subsequently able to capture Malta from Napoleon thanks to this victory by Horatio Nelson, whose fleet inflicted disastrous casualties on that of French admiral Brueys d'Aigalliers ("broy dye-gahl-YAY").

bonuses.leadin: In the 1990s, a group of authors from this country published the "Crack Manifesto" seeking to rebuff exoticism in literature. For 10 points each:
answers: Mexico [or United Mexican States or Estados Unidos Mexicanos] (The other author is Yuri Herrera.)
Italo Calvino (The novel is Invisible Cities.)
One Hundred Years of Solitude [or Cien años de soledad]
parts: Name this home country of a realist author who wrote the novels Kingdom Cons and Signs Preceding the End of the World.

The "Crack Manifesto" suggests that its themes are best described by this non-Mexican author's Six Memos for the Next Millennium. One of his novels is framed as a dialogue between Kubla Khan and Marco Polo.
Mexico's "Crack Generation" is often grouped with Chile's McOndo movement, whose name parodies that of the town where Leaf Storm and this other Gabriel Garcia Marquez novel are set.
answers_formatted: One Hundred Years of Solitude [or Cien años de soledad]
metadata: The other author is Yuri Herrera.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the genetics of cancer:
answers: loss-of-function AND gain-of-function [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
parts: Cancer development is often precipitated by the loss of this property, in which the individual has two different alleles for the same gene.

Cancer-causing mutations can be categorized using these two hyphenated terms, which describe whether the gene product fails to do something it's supposed to, or if it does something new it isn't supposed to. Name both.
15% of all colorectal cancers are associated with this hypermutable condition, in which defects in mismatch repair cause the creation of small DNA fragments comprised of short tandem repeats.
answers_formatted: loss-of-function AND gain-of-function [do not accept or prompt on "partial answers"]

bonuses.leadin: These people's name derives from a French word describing explorers who cooked and sold smoked meat. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these semi-lawful sailors who harassed Spanish ports in the Caribbean for the English. With pirates, they formed a loose coalition known as the Brethren of the Coast.

Many buccaneers, including Henry Morgan and Edward Mansvelt, had their base at this colony's city of Port Royal. Escaped slaves known as maroons fought a series of wars with the British on this island colony.
Many buccaneers were mobilized to defend against Michel de Ruyter's siege of this island. In 1816, Bussa led a massive slave rebellion on this island.
